nodes.bodyText: As per conversation with Sameekhsa and Anu, core team will provide withContext, fluxContext api with map attributes to handle nested calls on sdk more cleanly
This overload should already be available to use on latest core i.e <version>1.4.0-beta.1</version>
Checked offline with Sameeksha 1.4.0-beta.1 does not have the requested overload
Discussed with Sameeksha offline , as of now cosmos sdk wont need it
Ending span on very first element of pagedFlux , avoiding accountability of any user side delay. Please let me know if anyone think other wise and want it on OnComplete()
@trask Would like to know your thoughts on the expected behavior, if we should end the span of the first element received.

@simplynaveen20 @samvaity That's a great question! I think that ideally it would capture until complete, while at the same time somehow capturing the internal time that was spent waiting on cosmosdb. Maybe the diagnostic data returned from the cosmosdb server could represent the internal time, as event(s) on the overarching span? This doesn't have to be part of the initial work though, and it's ok if you want to end the span on first element until we have a way to separate cosmosdb internal time from (external) user time while iterating over results.
Moved to to doOnComplete()(It will include both sdk + user side time). However we have diagnostics to find out exact time taken by SDK
oh, nice, will that be part of the diagnostics that we capture in the next phase?
Yea actually I am thinking of cleaning this , and some other ones too  .Thank for suggestion . Will send it in next iteration
Done

Moved the PR out draft version, did bunch of refactoring , and I like your third option i.e using
CallDepth (more intuitive for code readability)  , thanks for advice :)
these 3 methods look the same other than mapping response to status code. maybe extract out private method that also takes a Function<T, Integer> and delegate to that?
Done
hasKey never returns null
Removed this method usage
Moved to CallDepth enum, all set on this
probably should prefix/namespace these since they are put into the reactor context, just to make sure they don't conflict with anything that users may put into there
Not needed anymore

Given the requirements to set these specific attributes on every span it would help if we could use
local = tracer.start(methodName, local); // will start the span
tracer.setAttribute(DB_INSTANCE, "myDatabaseName", local); // use the current span to set attributes on it
This way we don't have to add a new ProcessKind and this startSpan overload can be used as it.
Removed ProcessKind dependency.
this logs the query text? If the query has private info, this will get logged? is that ok?

seems this code is repeated exactly, can this be factored out as a function and passed here?
\liked this
return withContext(context -> replace(containerProperties, requestOptions, context))
    .subscriberContext(reactorContext -> factoredOutFunc())
I was waiting on final handshake between cosmos and core for withContext api, did the refactoring now.
Done

does this log the user query? is that ok? user query may have private info?
"queryItems." + this.getId() + "." + sqlQuerySpec.getQueryText();
@trask  whats your thought on this , I think @moderakh has a point here.

For jdbc, we only capture PreparedStatement query templates, and not the actual bind parameters provided by the user. We do something similar for MongoDB and other databases. is querytext a parameterized query template? or are bind parameters already embedded into it?

Cosmos have two api for query , one take plain text with parameter embedded into it and second takes SqlQuerySpec , which is template based. For plain text query, code itself create SqlQuerySpec and use common code flow as above.
We have two option here -

Only log query if user uses SqlQuerySpec  api , but this will be inconsistent.
Log for both as it is happening now , assuming for all the sensitive query user will use SqlQuerySpec  api.
Don't log query text any of the apis.

I would go with option 1 , as I can take inconsistency over possibility of leaking private info. Option 3 will be my second choice
Thoughts ?

yes, option 1 sounds good. we still want to capture a span for plain text queries, but use something more generic for the span name and db.statement attribute, e.g. the same value that you put into db.instance would be acceptable
done

can we factor out this code, here and other places?
e.g,
return withContext(context -> replaceItem(itemType, itemId, doc, requestOptions,context))
    .subscriberContext(reactorContext -> factoredOutFunc())
Done
Done
ditto, here and other places.
Done
Does documentDB refer to us? if so, that name is deprecated.

This is the supported resource provider list of Azure services that gives the value Microsoft.DocumentDB for Cosmos.
Feature request to include this on all Track 2 SDK's - #7049

@samvaity it seems as per the link you shared the resource provider name of our service is not updated from Microsoft.DocumentDB to Microsoft.Cosmos.
@samvaity My question to you is if for tracer work, this is merge implementation details or whether in the application insight the customers will see the term "DocumentDB" ?
FYI @kirankumarkolli

The customers would see the term "DocumentDB".
I think the ask was from the Azure Monitor team to be able to group spans/trace information for a particular Azure service and wanted to follow consistent naming across different components (i. Azure Monitor).

Azure Monitor exporter will use this information to navigate to the corresponding Azure resource from AzMon UX and show proper icons. #7049

I agree we should not follow deprecated naming but then is this listed incorrectly on the list too?
@trask Do you think if Cosmos should still be referred to as Microsoft.DocumentDB?

Our SDK names already deviate from the RP name.
Just for context: "Azure Cosmos DB" is the new branding (and RP will rebrand eventually).
For all Track2 libraries: How about using the package name 'Azure.Cosmos" in our specific case?
/cc: @JonathanGiles
Discussed with Sameeksha , once the documentation here  updates with azure.cosmosdb, we will change in the code too. Other azure services are also mentioned as Microsoft currently.
shouldn't this be "cosmos" instead of "cosmosdb"
@trask  ?
both are good from my perspective 👍
The brand of our service, our package name, etc, is cosmos. So this should match that.
For consistency on SDK lets use "Cosmos"

The withContext overload would be used for context passing and not just tracing context-related so should be included regardless of tracing presence.
@srnagar
We don't want any perf hit due to tracing code flow if user has not opt in the tracing. Unless we have any requirement which need with context , and that will be out of scope of this PR
@samvaity is right, context is used not just for tracing. So, !getTracerProvider().isEnabled() is not the right check to determine whether to use withContext() or not.
as discussed offline will introduce this on demand

I would like this to be resolved within this PR - Context is general purpose and not specifically tied to tracing. That it is treated as such here means that we are not following convention and users who are using Context for other purposes, e.g. in their own http policies, will get a surprise when the context is not properly propagating for them.

With context having perf hit , if we do it on all, then non tracer user will get affected , already communicated to Sameeksha and Srikanta. We will track it as separate item and will introduce it on demand and we will then revisit perf again.
Should this span name be createDatabaseIfNotExists and not internal?
Version should have a version tag similar to the one azure-core has <!-- {x-version-update;com.azure:azure-core;dependency} -->

nodes.bodyText:
callDepth cannot be null as you are doing getOrDefault in the previous line.
Also, it's better to use if (callDepth == null) { throw exception; } instead of using assert. If the assertion fails, it throws AssertionError extends from Error which is considered fatal and the program cannot recover.
as discussed offline , it is due to spot bug
This code segment is common for both overloads of createDatabaseIfNotExistsInternal. Consider extracting into a common method instead of repeating it.
excluding only boring ssl should be sufficient.

this will have additional cost even if tracer not enabled.

we should short circuit this if tracer is not enabled.

id is the id of the container. so it means in the scope of this container "createItem." + this.getId() can be pre-computed for the container, rather than re-computing it each time.
Could you pre-compute this in the container level.

id is the id of the container. so it means in the scope of this container "readAllItems." + this.getId() can be pre-computed for the container, rather than re-computing it each time.
Could you pre-compute this in the container level.
here and other places.

"readItem." + this.getId() can be pre-computed in container rather than re-computing each time.
please pre-compute in the container.
and for similar other operations.

CosmosPagedFlux allows both paginated iteration and also item by item iteration.
I see that we covered the pageByPage iteration through adding CosmosPagedFlux#byPage(.) what about the item by item iteration shoudldn't we cover that as well?

remove this comment?

Initially we had non cosmosResponse api returning Mono, now we removed those api , so removing this method altogether

do we think this is a good idea?
especially since Throwable.printStackTrace() isn't thread-safe and could give out confusing logs/statements?
cc: @srnagar

I don't think we should have the entire stacktrace in tracing. It's important to capture that there was an error but the stracktrace is likely not that useful. Stacktrace should be available in logs, if that's necessary. It's also a security issue to capture stacktrace since the user cannot control or turn it off.
Removed the error stacktrace
